The rain didn't so much fall as it seeped, a fine, persistent mist that clung to the brickwork of Southwark and made the cobblestones gleam like polished teeth. It was a miserable sort of wetness, the kind that got under your collar and into your bones, a constant reminder of the city's damp, ancient heart. Doctor Aris Leach felt it in the ache of a shrapnel wound that had never quite healed, a phantom throb in her left thigh that always picked up the beat of a London drizzle. She pulled the collar of her heavy wool coat tighter, the fabric smelling of damp earth and something vaguely antiseptic, a scent that followed her from one grim location to the next.

This one was an alleyway tucked between a derelict tannery and a pub whose windows were opaque with grime. The air was thick with the ghosts of industry, the tang of iron from the river, and the more recent, cloying sweetness of cheap perfume. A single red shoe, a high heel, lay on its side in a puddle, a splash of defiant colour in a world of grey. It was the only thing left of Amelia Croft, aged twenty-six, a trainee solicitor who’d had the misfortune of taking a shortcut.

"Right then, Doctor," said a voice to her right. Detective Inspector Finch, a man whose weary face looked as though it had been carved from a block of lard and left too near a radiator. "He's done it again. Same as the others."

Aris didn't look at him. Her eyes were fixed on the wall. "Not quite the same, Inspector."

Finch sighed, a sound like a punctured tyre. "Woman goes missing. No witnesses. No struggle. Leaves a bit of herself behind. Looks the same to me."

"The stain," Aris said, her voice low. It was a flat, northern tone, a Salford burr that hadn't been softened by years in the army or months in the capital. It made Londoners either listen closer or dismiss her entirely. Finch was still deciding which. "It's bigger."

On the grimy brick, a smear of impossible, lurid yellow. It wasn’t paint, not precisely. Aris had seen the lab reports on the samples from the other three scenes. Inconclusive. Organic compounds mixed with industrial pigments, traces of sulphur and something protein-based they couldn't identify. It had the texture of dried egg yolk and the faint, unsettling smell of ozone and damp clay. This time, it wasn't just a splash. It was a wide, sweeping arc, starting near the ground and curving up, up, over seven feet high, ending in what looked horribly like the imprint of a massive thumb. As if something had casually leaned against the wall, bracing itself, before plucking a woman from the world.

Aris crouched down, ignoring the damp seeping into the knees of her trousers. She ran a gloved finger near the edge of the red shoe. The ground around it was scuffed, but not in the way you’d expect from a fight. It was a single, deep impression, a divot in the compacted earth of the alley. She looked from the divot to the yellow thumbprint high on the wall. The geometry of it was all wrong. The physics were a lie.

"Any other anomalies?" she asked, her gaze sweeping the narrow space. The police search had been thorough in its own plodding way. They’d looked for fibres, for footprints, for discarded weapons. They were looking for a man. Aris knew, with a certainty that chilled her more than the rain, that they were looking for the wrong thing.

"Just the usual," Finch grumbled. "Bin's been knocked over down the end."

Aris stood, her joints cracking a soft protest. She walked the length of the alley, her boots crunching on loose gravel. The industrial bin was on its side, its contents—sodden cardboard and the refuse of the pub—spilled across the ground. But it wasn't just knocked over. One side was deeply concave, a huge dent in the thick sheet metal, as if it had been kicked by a horse. Or squeezed. She saw something else, too. A piece of iron drainpipe, thick as her wrist, had been bent at a ninety-degree angle where it jutted from the wall, about five feet up. It was snapped clean from its housing. She touched the cold, fractured metal. The force required… it was absurd.

"That's new," she murmured to herself.

Finch had waddled up behind her. "Vandals. Kids. Happens all the time."

"Does it, Inspector?" Aris turned to face him, her eyes, the colour of a stormy sea, holding his. "In the same alley, on the same night that a woman vanishes into thin air, leaving behind a stain of unidentifiable biological matter and a thumbprint the size of a dinner plate?"

Finch’s jowls wobbled. He looked from her to the bent pipe and back again. The certainty in his own procedural world was beginning to crack. "What are you suggesting, Doctor? That the Incredible Hulk’s come to South London for a bit of a sing-song?"

"I'm suggesting we stop ignoring the details that don't fit the narrative of a man with a van and a bag of lime." She pulled a small sampling kit from her coat pocket, scraping a flake of the yellow substance from the high thumbprint into a vial. The brick was rough under her scraper, but the yellow material came away cleanly, like a scab. "He's getting bolder. Or hungrier."

Back in the sterile white box they called her office, a temporary space in a forgotten corner of New Scotland Yard, the files of the other victims were spread across her desk. Three women before Amelia Croft. There was Elodie, the ballerina, who disappeared from a Covent Garden side street. Her ballet slipper was left, filled with rainwater. Then came Maria, the cellist, taken from outside a rehearsal hall in Islington. They found her cello case, empty, with a single, furious yellow slash across it. And then Chloe, the soup kitchen volunteer, who vanished from a street in Whitechapel, leaving only a dropped ladle.

Dancer. Musician. Charity worker. Solicitor. Aris stared at their photographs. They were all different ages, different backgrounds, different ethnicities. But they all had it. A light in their eyes. In the photos, they were all laughing, or smiling, or caught in a moment of unguarded joy. They were women who shone. It wasn't about sex or money. It was about something else entirely. It was about their radiance. He was a collector of lights, and he extinguished them one by one, leaving only his own jaundiced signature in their place.

Jealousy. The thought came to her unbidden, sharp and clear. It was a motive as old as humanity, but this felt different. Primal. This wasn't the bitter envy of a spurned lover or a failed colleague. This was something vaster. The jealousy of a shadow for the sun.

She pulled up the crime scene photographs on her monitor, flicking between them. Elodie’s scene: a snapped iron railing on a nearby fence, noted in the file as 'pre-existing urban decay'. Maria’s scene: a heavy stone planter, cracked from top to bottom, 'likely frost damage'. Chloe’s scene: a brick wall, crumbled, 'poor-quality mortar'. And now, Amelia's scene, with its crushed bin and bent drainpipe.

Finch and his ilk saw a dozen unrelated acts of minor vandalism. Aris Leach, who had once put a man back together after he’d been hit by an IED, who knew precisely what kinetic energy did to bone and metal, saw a single, terrifying pattern. She saw the tracks of something impossibly strong. Something huge.

She leaned back, the cheap office chair groaning. The city hummed outside her window, a sprawling, indifferent beast. Four women gone. A giant, fuelled by envy, stalking the streets of London, eating women who shone too brightly and painting their memory yellow. It sounded like a madman's fairytale, a forgotten piece of grotesque folklore come to life. But the samples in her lab and the ache in her leg told her it was real. The press, in their predictable fashion, had dubbed him the 'Canary Killer'. They had no idea how inadequate the name was.

Her phone buzzed. It was a text from her liaison at the lab. *'Preliminary on the new sample. Same composition. But the protein markers are… different. More concentrated. And Aris… we found traces of human digestive enzymes.'*

Aris closed her eyes. It wasn't just a signature. It wasn't just paint. It was a byproduct. A regurgitation. The final, disgusting insult. He painted them yellow because that was what was left of them inside him.

She opened her eyes, stood up, and walked to the window. The lights of London glittered below, millions of tiny lives, millions of little flames in the dark. One of them was a monster. And she, a doctor of medicine and a veteran of a forgotten war, a woman from the rain-soaked streets of Salford, was the only person who seemed to see the size of the shadow he cast. A cold resolve settled over her, heavy and familiar as her coat. Right then. Let’s get to it. The city was a hunting ground, and the game was afoot.She shrugged back into the heavy wool coat, the motion automatic, the familiar weight a strange comfort against the formless dread coalescing inside her. The office suddenly felt too small, its white walls a closing trap. She swept the victims' files back into a single, neat pile, handling their faces with a reverence that felt inadequate. They deserved justice, but the word felt thin and brittle when faced with the reality of what had happened to them. They hadn't just been murdered; they had been consumed, rendered down to their basest components, and what was left was a mocking, yellow smear on a grimy wall. Justice seemed a paltry thing to offer in return for such an obscene violation.

The walk to the deep-level labs was a descent, both literally and figuratively. She left the drab carpets and bureaucratic hum of the main floors behind, taking a dedicated lift down into the building’s concrete heart. Here, the air was chilled and scrubbed clean, the corridors were painted a sterile, glossy white, and the silence was broken only by the whir of ventilation and the quiet beeping of machines that spent their days searching for truth in the microscopic. It was a world away from the grime of the Southwark alley, yet Aris felt the connection between the two places like an electric current. This was where the monster’s spoor was dissected, where its nature would be laid bare, if only they had the courage to look.

Ben Carter was waiting for her in Lab 3. He was a decade younger than her, a wiry man with hair that stood up in a permanent state of surprise and eyes that were magnified by thick glasses. He practically vibrated with a nervous intelligence that Aris found both exhausting and useful. He had already projected the mass spectrometer readings onto a large wall-mounted screen. A chaotic festival of coloured peaks and troughs, it was a language she only partially understood.
"Aris. It's weirder than I thought," he said, skipping any pleasantries. He pointed a laser at a jagged series of green spikes on the screen. "Standard human proteome on the left. That's the baseline, from residual skin cells on the shoe. On the right… that's the yellow stuff. The primary proteins are human, yes. But they're sheared, hydrolysed—basically, torn to shreds. And the enzymes that did it…" He zoomed in on another section, a flurry of angry-looking red lines. "Pepsin, trypsin, sure. But there's something else mixed in, a catalyst I've never seen before. It works like a super-acid, but it’s organic. It breaks down everything, collagen, keratin, even the enamel of teeth, at a terrifying rate. There shouldn’t be anything left, but it seems… inefficient."

Aris stared at the data, the abstract lines translating into a horrific mental image. A digestive system of impossible power, yet somehow sloppy. "In a normal digestive tract, the enzymes are contained. They break down food, the nutrients are absorbed, waste is… processed," she said, her voice quiet. "This is different. This is like the whole process happened externally, or was violently reversed."
"Exactly!" Ben’s excitement was macabre. "It’s like a flash-digestion followed by a… purge. A regurgitation. The killer isn't leaving a mark, Doctor. He's leaving his vomit. And the concentration is off the charts this time. The previous samples were faint traces. This one is potent. It suggests the digestive process is becoming more effective. Or, as you put it, he’s getting hungrier."

A profound, visceral sickness rose in her. It wasn't just envy. It was predation. The creature stalking London wasn't a collector of lights; it was a consumer of them. It was feeding on the very essence of these women, on the vitality she had recognised in their photographs. The increased strength, the growing boldness, the more concentrated stain—it was all part of a single, terrifying metabolic process. The monster was growing. It was adapting to its new hunting ground. She thought of the bent drainpipe, the crushed bin. It wasn't just showing off. It was testing its own strength, like a growing adolescent. The thought was so bizarre, so far outside the realm of normal police work, that she almost laughed. The Incredible Hulk, Finch had scoffed. He was closer than he knew.

"Ben," she said, turning away from the screen, her sea-grey eyes locking onto his. "Look into mythology. Folklore. Anything you can find, from any culture, about creatures that feed on… life-force. On vitality. Things that are drawn to brightness, to joy."
Ben’s magnified eyes blinked. "You want me to run a search on… folkloric predators? In the Met's forensic database?"
"No," Aris corrected, her Salford accent clipping the word. "I want you to use your own considerable, and I suspect, non-regulation access to every university and occult library database on the planet. Forget police procedure. The thing we're hunting doesn't follow it. We're looking for a fairytale, Ben. A horrible, grimy, real-life fairytale that has crawled into London to feed." She saw the flicker of doubt in his eyes, warring with the sheer, undeniable weirdness of the science in front of him. "Just do it," she added, her voice softening slightly. "Humour me. What have we got to lose?"Ben didn't need any more encouragement. The prospect of chasing a genuine scientific anomaly, even one wrapped in the archaic language of myth, was more than enough to set his formidable mind to the task. Aris left him to it, the door to the lab hissing shut behind her, sealing him in with his screens and his strange new quest. The lift ascended silently, carrying her back up through the layers of the building, each floor she passed a step further away from the cold, hard data and a step closer to the incomprehensible reality it described. The certainty she had felt in the lab began to fray at the edges, replaced by the professional loneliness of knowing something that you could never, ever say aloud. It was one thing to entertain a theory about a monster in the sterile confines of a forensics lab; it was another to carry that knowledge out into the corridors of power, where men like Finch carved the world into neat, manageable boxes.

As if summoned by the thought, the Inspector was waiting for her when the lift doors opened, his bulk filling the narrow hallway. He was holding a flimsy sheet of paper as if it were a winning lottery ticket, a rare glimmer of satisfaction momentarily smoothing the deep-set lines of his face. He’d found a piece that fit his puzzle, and he was proud of it.
“Good news, Doctor,” he announced, the words rumbling in his chest. “We’ve got a person of interest. Name’s Gary Tibbett. Local bloke, lives a few streets over from the Croft girl’s alley. Got a record as long as your arm for harassment, indecent exposure. Likes to follow women home from the tube station. One of his previous victims said he threatened to ‘swallow her whole’. Fits the profile.”

Aris took the paper he offered. It was a standard background check, a photograph of a sallow-faced man with shifty eyes and a weak chin stapled to the corner. She could see why Finch was pleased. Tibbett was a perfect fit for a conventional crime. He was the piece you found and slotted into place, the ugly but simple answer that allowed everyone to sleep at night. But he was the wrong piece for this puzzle. She could feel it with the same instinct that made her shrapnel ache before the rain. She pictured Gary Tibbett, with his thin wrists and sloping shoulders, trying to crush a steel bin or snap a cast iron drainpipe. The image was laughable.
“And his alibi?” she asked, handing the paper back.
“At home with his mum, of course,” Finch said, the satisfaction already beginning to sour in the face of her lack of enthusiasm. “But she’s half-senile and he’s a proven liar.”
“Check his hands, Inspector,” Aris said, her voice flat. “Look for any bruising, any fractures. Ask him to lift a hundred kilograms with one arm. Ask him if he can jump seven feet from a standing start.”
Finch’s face began to revert to its usual melted state. “Now look here, Doctor. This is how we solve cases. We find the grubby little man with the nasty little habit and we put him away. We don't go looking for circus strongmen. Tibbett is a solid lead.”
“He’s a distraction,” Aris countered, her patience, a finite resource at the best of times, wearing dangerously thin. “He is the noise that stops you from hearing the signal. You are looking for a man who preys on the vulnerable. The person we are hunting, the thing we are hunting, does the opposite. It seeks out strength. It’s drawn to confidence, to talent, to joy. It doesn’t want the women who walk with their heads down. It wants the ones who shine.”

She pushed past him, not waiting for a response, and walked back into the sterile box of her office. The conversation had crystallised her thinking. It wasn't just about the victims’ inner light; it was about how they projected it. A ballerina on a Covent Garden stage, a cellist whose music filled a hall, a solicitor arguing a case, a charity worker whose compassion was a beacon in a place like Whitechapel. They were all performers in their own way, projecting their essence out into the world. And something had seen them. Something had coveted that energy and come to consume it. She went to the large map of London pinned to a corkboard on her wall, a relic from a previous, more geographically-focused investigation. She took four coloured pins from a drawer and began to push them into the map. Elodie in Covent Garden. Maria in Islington. Chloe in Whitechapel. Amelia in Southwark.

For a long time she just stared at them, four tiny points of plastic representing four extinguished lives. They formed a loose, ragged crescent across the central part of the city, bordering the snaking path of the Thames. There was no obvious geometric pattern, no simple A-to-B progression. But it wasn’t random, either. It was a territory. A hunting ground. The creature was prowling the old, dense heart of the city, the places where history and life were packed most tightly together, where a million lights, big and small, shone every night. Her eyes traced the spaces between the pins, the vast, dark patches of the city that remained untouched. It was there, somewhere in the sprawling, rain-slicked labyrinth of London, moving from one pool of light to the next. And it was growing. She could feel a cold clock ticking, its hand moving inexorably towards the next victim, the next bright soul it would pluck from the world. Her job wasn’t just to find it. Her job was to get there first.She traced the crescent on the map with her finger, from the tanneries of Southwark to the concert halls of Islington. It was a predator's territory, defined not by landmarks but by a specific type of prey. Her thinking had been too linear, too focused on the aftermath. To catch a predator, you had to understand its appetites. You had to find the watering hole. She turned from the grim geography of the dead and opened her laptop, the screen's bright glow illuminating her tired face. She didn't open a police database. She opened a listings website for London's West End.

The screen filled with a vibrant mosaic of human achievement. Sold-out musicals, avant-garde plays, breathtaking ballets, standing-room-only concerts. Each listing was a beacon, a concentrated point of the very energy the creature seemed to crave. She pictured the leading ladies, the virtuoso musicians, the charismatic actors, all of them standing on a stage under bright lights, pouring their talent and passion out into the darkness. They were making themselves into the most visible, most radiant targets imaginable. The thought felt obscene, like she was scouting victims, but this was the cold logic of the hunt. The creature wasn't just grabbing people from dark alleys; the alleys were just where it took them. The hunt began where the lights were brightest.

Meanwhile, in the sterile quiet of the deep-level lab, Ben Carter was falling down a rabbit hole. His initial searches had been a farcical exercise in twenty-first-century absurdity. Typing "monster that eats joy" into a search engine yielded a torrent of articles on workplace burnout and clinical depression. "Vitality-stealing entity" led him to forums dedicated to video game lore and overwrought teenage poetry. He was about to email Aris with a polite, "I'm drawing a blank," when he remembered the specificity of her mind, the way she clung to physical evidence. He pulled up his analysis of the yellow stain. *Sulphur. Damp clay. Unidentified protein catalyst.* He tried a new search, a combination of arcane and scientific terms: "folkloric predator" AND "sulphur" AND "clay" AND "regurgitation."

The internet's vast, commercialised surface fell away, and he plunged into the murky depths of digitised academic archives and obscure occult texts. Most of it was dross, but one hit, a poorly scanned dissertation on pre-Christian bog-mythology from the Low Countries, made him sit bolt upright. It spoke of a creature known in local dialects as the *Lichtzehrer*—the Light-Eater. A thing of mud and shadow, born of the sour, damp earth, that was drawn to the brightest expressions of human life: a talented singer, a brilliant craftsman, a woman famous for her beauty or kindness. The legends claimed it could not create anything itself, and so, in an act of profound, elemental jealousy, it consumed those who could. The texts said the *Lichtzehrer* left behind a jaundiced, foul-smelling secretion, a 'bile of envy', often on walls or stones. Ben’s blood ran cold. He wasn't looking at a fairytale. He was looking at a field guide.

Aris didn't wait for Ben's findings. A cold, restless energy had taken hold of her, the same feeling she used to get before a patrol, the hum of imminent action. Remaining in her office felt like hiding. She shed her work trousers and blouse, pulling on dark, unremarkable jeans and a grey cashmere jumper. She traded her sensible office shoes for a pair of soft-soled, waterproof boots. She kept the heavy wool coat, shrugging into its familiar weight like a knight donning a piece of battered, reliable armour. Before she left, her hand hovered over the service pistol locked in her desk drawer. It was a pointless consideration. What good was a 9mm pistol against something that could bend iron pipes with its bare hands? She took a canister of military-grade pepper spray and a torch whose focused beam could momentarily blind a man at fifty yards. They felt like children's toys.

The electric vibrancy of Shaftesbury Avenue hit her like a physical blow. After the damp quiet of the crime scenes and the sterile silence of her office, it was a sensory assault. Thousands of people, a river of humanity, flowed along the pavements, their faces illuminated by the neon and gold of a dozen theatre marquees. The air, still damp from the earlier drizzle, seemed to crackle with anticipation and excitement. Laughter echoed off the grand Victorian facades. To every other person there, it was a backdrop for a night of pleasure and escape. To Aris, it was an all-you-can-eat buffet for a monster, and every bright, shining face was a potential dish. She felt a surge of protective fury, so fierce and so futile that it almost choked her.

She found a strategic position in a shadowed doorway across from the Gielgud Theatre, letting the tide of theatre-goers part around her. From there, she watched. She tried to decouple her mind from human aesthetics, to see the crowd as the creature might. She ignored the fashionable clothes, the pretty faces, the overt displays of wealth. She looked for the spark. She saw it in a young couple, their heads close together, sharing a joke that made them both throw their heads back in uninhibited laughter. She saw it in a woman standing alone, looking up at the theatre's name in lights, her expression one of pure, unadulterated ambition and hope. And she saw it, with an intensity that made her breath catch, in the theatre's leading lady, who had just stepped from a black car, waving to a small knot of fans, her smile a megawatt beacon of practiced charisma and genuine delight.

A sharp, stabbing pain flared in her left thigh, a jolt from the old shrapnel that was more intense than usual. It was her body's barometer, not just for the weather, but for wrongness. A cold spot seemed to be spreading through the cheerful atmosphere, a subtle drop in temperature that had nothing to do with the night air. The ambient noise of the crowd seemed to dip for a split second, a flutter in the soundscape like a tape being chewed. Her eyes were drawn away from the actress, past the lights, to the deep, absolute shadows of a narrow service alley between two theatres. Nothing moved. But the darkness there felt different. It felt… occupied. It had weight. Aris’s hand went instinctively to the heavy coat, her fingers brushing the cold metal of the pepper spray canister. The game was afoot, and she was standing in the middle of the board.She took a slow, deliberate step away from the doorway, letting the river of people swallow her. She moved with an unnatural economy of motion, a predator’s glide learned not in alleys but in the dusty, sun-scorched streets of a foreign war. She didn't look at the alley directly, instead keeping her eyes on the reflective glass of a souvenir shop, watching the dark opening in the periphery as she closed the distance. The cold intensified with every yard, a pocket of winter in the mild autumn night. And then came the smell, a phantom on the edge of the city's olfactory chaos. It was the scent from the crime scene, but raw and alive: the ozone tang of a coming storm, the mineral funk of river mud, and the unsettling, cloying sweetness that she now understood was not cheap perfume, but the aroma of recent consumption. It was the smell of a full stomach.

Her phone vibrated in her coat pocket, a frantic, insistent buzz that was utterly alien to the primeval tension of the moment. She nearly ignored it, but the caller ID flashed with Ben’s name. She ducked into the lee of a public relations kiosk, turning her back to the street as she answered, her voice a low command. “What is it?” His words came in a breathless torrent, a cascade of discovery and horror. He spoke of Low Country myths, of bog-folk and sour earth, of a name that landed in her mind with the weight of a coffin lid: *Lichtzehrer*. The Light-Eater. A creature of shadow and clay, motivated by a cosmic jealousy, that consumed vitality and left only a sulphurous, regurgitated bile in its wake. Every word he spoke was a new rivet hammered into the framework of the impossible truth she was staring at.

“The texts say it’s barely sentient in the way we understand it,” Ben stammered, his scientific detachment completely shattered. “More like a force of nature, an instinct given form. It’s drawn to the brightest lights because it has no light of its own. Aris, it’s not just a killer, it’s a… a negative. A void. The physics of the thing are a lie because it’s a lie made manifest.” Aris’s knuckles were white where she gripped the phone. The ache in her thigh was a screaming siren now. She could feel the void’s proximity, a profound and absolute emptiness that was pulling the warmth from the air, the light from the neon, the very life from the street. “Ben,” she said, her own voice sounding distant to her ears. “It’s here. I’m looking at its nest.”

She ended the call without waiting for his reply, her focus narrowing to the tight, black mouth of the alley. The cheerful cacophony of Shaftesbury Avenue seemed to recede, muffled as if by thick glass. She was alone with it now. She took the final ten steps, her soft-soled boots making no sound on the pavement. She stood at the precipice, the cold air washing over her, heavy with its foul, tell-tale odour. She raised the heavy-duty torch and thumbed the switch. The beam, a brilliant white spear of focused light, stabbed into the darkness. It did not reveal a grimy brick wall. The light struck a surface that was a deep, wet, loamy brown, textured like packed mud and glistening with moisture. It was a pillar, impossibly thick and tall, that rose up into the darkness beyond the reach of her beam. It was not masonry. It was a leg.

For a heartbeat, nothing happened. Then, high above her, something shifted. A deep, resonant hum vibrated through the ground, a sound felt in the bones more than heard, the thrum of a vast and ancient engine waking up. A cascade of grit and loose mortar pattered down onto the alley floor. Then, a section of the colossal limb in front of her seemed to bulge, to swell, and from the glistening dark mass, a shape began to resolve. It was an eye. A globe of polished jet the size of her head, utterly without pupil or sclera, that swiveled slowly down to fix upon the source of the light. There was no malice in it, no intelligence she could recognise. There was only a vast, cold, and eternal hunger. The *Lichtzehrer* had been disturbed at its meal, and it was looking back.### Chapter 2

Time seemed to stutter and warp in the narrow confines of the alley. For Aris, who had once timed the gap between a sniper’s shot and its impact to the hundredth of a second, the moment stretched into an eternity. The eye, a perfect, unblinking sphere of black, reflected the beam of her torch, a tiny white star in an infinite void. It held no expression, just an absolute, patient attention. This was a fear beyond the simple terror of the battlefield, where the threat was at least human, born of the same flesh and blood. This was a primal, geological dread, the fear of an ant realizing the mountain it was climbing was alive and had just noticed it. The low hum intensified, a vibration that travelled up through the soles of her boots and into her teeth, making them ache.

Her training screamed at her. *Break contact. Disorient. Retreat to a defensible position.* But every tactical instinct she possessed was predicated on an enemy that obeyed the laws of physics, an opponent who could be flanked, suppressed, or neutralized. Her thumb slid from the torch’s switch, a half-conscious move to plunge the alley back into darkness, to sever the visual tether that bound her to the creature. But she stopped herself. In the dark, it would have every advantage. The light, however insignificant, was her only claim on this space, her only tool. She took a single, agonizingly slow step backward, the gravel crunching under her boot with a sound that seemed as loud as a gunshot in the sudden, profound silence that had fallen between them.

The creature responded to her movement. It did not lurch or leap, but shifted its immense weight with a grinding, deliberate slowness that spoke of unimaginable power held in reserve. The muddy pillar of its leg contracted, muscles of packed earth and river-dredge flexing. High above, out of the darkness, a second limb descended. It was not an arm, not in any biological sense. It was a colossal, branching appendage of the same dark, wet clay, ending in a thick, five-fingered mass that could have palmed a delivery van. One of those digits, a thumb the size of a manhole cover, scraped against the brickwork with a sound like a tombstone being dragged across concrete. It left a wet, viscous smear on the wall—a glistening, lurid yellow. Aris stared, mesmerized in her terror. The signature wasn't a mark it left deliberately. It was something that simply leaked from it, an incidental byproduct of its existence, like a slug’s trail.

The sight of the yellow smear broke the spell. The detached, analytical part of her brain that had been frozen by awe and terror suddenly rebooted. This was it. The killer. The source. The grotesque, impossible truth. The appendage continued its descent, not with speed, but with an inexorable certainty that was far more frightening. It wasn't reaching for her. It was simply moving into the space she occupied, as if she were of no more consequence than the air itself. Her retreat became a desperate, clumsy scramble. She turned and ran, the three short steps to the mouth of the alley feeling like a mile. She burst from the cold, silent pocket of dread back into the riot of sound and colour on Shaftesbury Avenue. She stumbled into a couple, who grunted in annoyance, their faces painted with the carefree glow of a Friday night. They righted themselves and moved on, absorbed back into the river of humanity, oblivious.

Her mind, a fortress built of discipline and trauma, slammed its shutters against the sublime terror of the broadcast and focused on the single, vital task. The thin green line of the progress bar. It crept forward, a snail’s pace against the lightning-fast cascade of alien data. Ninety-two percent. The catwalk beneath her feet began to vibrate violently, not from a simple mechanical shudder, but from a sympathetic resonance with the immense power being channelled through the chamber. She gripped the console to steady herself, her knuckles white. The pulsing heart of the crystal was no longer a soft violet but a blinding, searing magnesium-white, a miniature sun that bleached all colour from the world, casting sharp, dancing shadows that seemed to have a life of their own. Ninety-five percent. The hum rose in pitch, climbing octaves into a piercing, glass-like shriek that threatened to shatter the very air. She felt a profound pressure in her skull, as if her own consciousness was a vessel being filled to the breaking point with a language it was never meant to contain.

The crescendo arrived not with a bang, but with a moment of absolute, perfect tonal clarity. The shriek coalesced into a single, pure note of impossible pitch and power. At that instant, a column of coherent, shimmering energy, a solid beam of visible information, erupted from the apex of the crystal. It lanced upwards with silent, terrifying speed, passing through the roof of the chamber as if it were not there, aimed squarely at the central radome high above. The displacement of energy created a concussive blast of air that tore across the gantry, nearly ripping her from her footing. Red warning sigils flashed across the console, screaming of thermal overloads and critical energy flux, the machine itself groaning under the strain of its own divine performance. Ninety-nine percent. The beam of light held steady, a pillar connecting the heart of the Earth to the cold, listening dark of space.

Then, as suddenly as it began, it was over. The beam vanished. The pure, piercing note collapsed back into silence. The blinding white light of the crystal faded, returning to its soft, violet, sleeping pulse. The thousands of glowing lenses on the chamber walls went dark, plunging the vast space into a near-absolute blackness, broken only by the faint glow of the console and the crystal’s distant heart. A small, green light on her data-jack blinked once, steady and final. The transfer was complete. She ripped the device from the console just as the holographic display changed, the beautiful, complex song replaced by a single, stark, red message in plain, brutal English. *EXTERNAL DATA BREACH DETECTED. ARECIBO PROTOCOL COMPROMISED. INITIATING SANITIZATION PROTOCOL. FACILITY PURGE IN T-MINUS 60 SECONDS.* A countdown timer began, its numbers dropping with merciless speed. The silence was not an end; it was the prelude to a new and final violence. The facility was about to sterilize itself, and her with it. She turned and ran, her soft-soled shoes slapping against the metal of the catwalk, a desperate, frantic rhythm against the silent, ticking clock of her own impending erasure.### Chapter 10

The sixty-second countdown was not a threat; it was a death sentence delivered in the cold, impartial language of a machine. There was no time for awe, no room for terror. Aris’s mind, stripped bare of everything but the primal imperative to survive, became a realm of pure, cold calculation. Sixty seconds to cross one hundred feet of exposed gantry, exit a magnetically sealed door, and clear the blast radius of a weapon she could not begin to comprehend. She was already moving, her body a coiled spring releasing into a dead sprint, the stolen data-jack clutched in her fist like a sacred relic. The metal catwalk rang under her pounding feet, each footfall a frantic drumbeat against the merciless, silent ticking of the clock. The vast, silent chamber, once a place of sublime, alien beauty, was now just a pit, a grave she was desperately trying to climb out of.

As the timer on her mental clock passed fifty, the facility began its final, violent preparations. A new hum resonated through the structure, deeper and more aggressive than the song it had just sung, the sound of colossal capacitors charging for a final, cataclysmic discharge. The sterile, cold air began to heat rapidly, a dry, baking heat that promised incineration. The metal of the gantry grew warm beneath her hands as she vaulted a section of damaged railing, a ghost of the immense energy about to be unleashed. The purge was not a chemical agent or a simple explosive; it was an act of purification by fire, a blast of plasma or focused energy designed to turn the entire chamber and everything in it back into its constituent atoms, leaving not even a shadow of compromise behind. It was the ultimate redaction, written in the language of pure power.

She reached the exit as the countdown dropped below twenty. The immense tungsten door, which had slid open with such a polite hiss, was now sliding shut with the slow, inexorable certainty of a tombstone being lowered into place. The gap was shrinking, a vertical slit of the dark Highland night narrowing with every precious second. There was no time to search for a manual override, no hope of fighting the titanic machinery that drove it. With ten seconds left, the gap was no wider than a man’s shoulders. Aris didn't break stride. She lowered her own shoulder, tucked her head, and launched herself through the narrowing aperture in a desperate, bruising dive. She hit the gravel outside hard, rolling to dissipate the impact, the rough stones tearing at her clothes and skin. Behind her, with a deep, final thud that vibrated through the ground, the tungsten door sealed itself shut, entombing the chamber forever.

She scrambled to her feet, not daring to look back, and ran. She was outside the mausoleum, but she was still deep within the facility's perimeter, a lone figure on a barren stage as the final act began. The hum from beneath the earth reached a fever pitch, and the three great radomes, the silent white skulls on the moor, began to glow. It was not the soft, pearlescent light of before, but a hard, angry, orange incandescence, the glow of a blast furnace reaching critical temperature. They were no longer listening devices; they had become the barrels of a planetary-scale weapon, aimed not at the stars, but at their own heart. She threw herself into the shallow depression of a drainage ditch as the world behind her turned to light.

With a deafening crack that split the air, the three radomes discharged. Three thick, incandescent beams of what looked like white-hot plasma lanced downwards, converging on the squat, black basalt building she had just escaped. The ground heaved as if struck by a meteor. The heat flash, a solid wall of palpable energy, washed over her, so intense she could feel it through the damp earth of the ditch. The basalt structure, a monument to impregnability, glowed a furious cherry-red for a single heartbeat, then a brilliant, searing white. It did not explode. It did not shatter. It simply ceased to be, dissolving into the blast, its matter unmade by the focused, unimaginable energy. The purge was absolute. Where the building had stood, there was now only a new, smoking crater of molten rock, glowing like a fresh wound in the earth.

The silence that rushed in to fill the void was absolute, broken only by the hiss of rain on superheated rock and the frantic, ragged sound of her own breathing. She pushed herself up, her body screaming in protest, every muscle bruised and strained. The adrenaline that had fuelled her desperate flight ebbed away, leaving behind a bone-deep exhaustion and a trembling that she could not control. The radomes were dark now, their surfaces scorched and smoking, their purpose fulfilled. The facility had committed suicide, taking its secrets with it. All except one. Stumbling through the dark, guided by instinct and the faint outline of the hills against the sky, she made her way back towards the ravine, back towards the world of the living, a fugitive carrying a ghost in a box.

Back in the cold, anonymous sanctuary of the van, the world shrank to the dimensions of the driver's seat. The storm outside lashed against the windows, but inside, there was only the sound of her own heartbeat slowly returning to normal. She locked the doors, the simple click of the mechanism a flimsy but comforting shield against the terrors of the night. The Pelican case sat on the passenger seat, solid and real. With hands that still shook, she opened it, took out her laptop and the precious data-jack. The connection was made, the transfer instantaneous. A single, complex icon, a crystalline fractal, appeared on her desktop. Its name was a quiet, damning accusation: *Arecibo Protocol*.

She clicked it. A universe of alien information bloomed on the screen, the star charts and equations she had glimpsed on the console. It was a library of impossible knowledge, a lifetime of study. But within it, nestled like a key in a lock, was a single, smaller file labelled ‘README_INTERNAL_MEMO_EYES_ONLY’. It was the human preface, the cliff notes to a cosmic opera. She opened it. The text was not technical or scientific. It was a policy document, a philosophical statement of intent, written with the cold, chilling clarity of Evelyn Grey’s voice. *'Asset entities (designation LI, KI, etc.) are not incursions. They are foundational components of a planetary-scale harmonic defense system, colloquially termed the "Choir". This system generates a sophisticated, multi-layered resonance field that acts as a cognitive camouflage, effectively rendering this solar system "uninteresting" to extra-solar intelligences of a predatory or expansionist nature. The Arecibo Protocol is not a message; it is a maintenance routine, a tuning fork to ensure the Choir remains in key. The LI-1 Cascade Event in London did not neutralize a threat; it destroyed a vital instrument, creating a "hole" in the harmonic shield. The primary directive of the Department for Ontological Security is not eradication, but maintenance and augmentation of this shield. We are not soldiers fighting a monster. We are keepers of a wall, and our only enemy is silence.'*

Aris stared at the screen, the words rearranging themselves in her mind, forming a new and infinitely more terrible reality. Her war, her righteous crusade, the bodies of the victims she had sought to avenge—all of it had been based on a catastrophic misunderstanding. The monsters were not the threat. They were the shield. And by smashing one to pieces in London, she hadn't saved the city. She had just rung the dinner bell for the entire universe.The rain that lashed against the van’s windscreen was a frantic, chaotic drumming, a stark contrast to the profound, dead silence that had fallen inside the vehicle, and inside Aris’s soul. The words on the laptop screen were not just text; they were a verdict, a final, damning judgment on her every action, her every conviction, since the day she had first crouched in a Southwark alley. The universe she had inhabited—a world of understandable, if monstrous, predators and the grim, familiar evil of men—dissolved like salt in water, replaced by a reality so vast, so alien, and so indifferent to human morality that her mind struggled to find purchase on its sheer, smooth surfaces. The silence in her leg, the blessed, hard-won peace she had mistaken for victory, was a lie. It was not the silence of a vanquished foe; it was the silence of a broken alarm, a disconnected sensor on a ship whose hull had just been breached.

The faces of the dead women, her personal pantheon of saints whose memory had fueled her crusade, returned to her now in a grotesque new light. Elodie the dancer, Maria the cellist, Amelia the solicitor; they were not victims of a random monster, but sacrificial fuel, human batteries plugged into a planetary machine, their brilliant, shining lives the necessary cost of keeping a cosmic horror at bay. The monster hadn't been jealous of their light; it had been harvesting it. And she, in her righteous, ignorant fury, had not avenged them. She had invalidated their sacrifice. She had smashed the machine they had died to power. The weight of this new, terrible guilt was a physical thing, a crushing pressure that threatened to splinter her sanity.

Then, through the crushing, tectonic weight of her guilt, a new feeling pushed its way to the surface: a pure, incandescent rage. It was an anger directed not at the dead creature of mud and envy, but at the living, calculating intelligence of the Department for Ontological Security. At Evelyn Grey and the cold, inhuman logic of the keepers of the wall. Why the deception? Why allow her, a 'high-impact variable', to operate in a vacuum of ignorance where the only possible outcome was the catastrophic one she had precipitated? Why the charade with Finch, the public disgrace, the elaborate theatre of her exile? The answer was as cold and clear as the text on the screen: she was expendable. The secret was not. They had seen her as a tool to be used and discarded, and when her actions threatened their grand, cosmic project, they had tried to erase her with the same dispassionate efficiency with which they tuned their monstrous choir.

She closed the laptop, the click of the lid a sound of finality, and secured it back in its case. The time for passive observation, for hiding in the shadows and listening, was over. Her war had been a mistake, a blunder of cosmic proportions, but the knowledge she now possessed made her the single most dangerous person on the planet to the silent, grey masters of the DOS. They would not stop hunting her. They would tear the world apart to reclaim the data she held, to silence the witness who had seen the inner workings of their machine. But they had miscalculated. They had profiled her as a soldier, a blunt instrument. They had failed to account for the doctor, the pathologist who could not rest until she understood the root cause of the disease. They had given her the enemy’s name; now she needed to see its face.

With a turn of the key, the van’s engine coughed to life, its mundane, mechanical rumble a defiant sound in the vast, ancient silence of the Highlands. She did not head south, back towards the imagined safety of the cities. The cities were traps, grids of surveillance and control. Her only sanctuary now lay in the opposite direction, in the wild, unobserved spaces, in the blind spots of the world where a ghost could still move unseen. She pulled the van onto the narrow, wet tarmac, the headlights cutting a weak, lonely path through the driving rain and the profound, absolute dark. She was no longer a soldier, a doctor, or even a fugitive. She was a witness, a custodian of the single most important and damning secret in human history. And she was driving into the heart of the storm to find out what happened next.

parts.text:
The rain didn't so much fall as it seeped, a fine, persistent mist that clung to the brickwork of Southwark and made the cobblestones gleam like polished teeth. It was a miserable sort of wetness, the kind that got under your collar and into your bones, a constant reminder of the city's damp, ancient heart. Doctor Aris Leach felt it in the ache of a shrapnel wound that had never quite healed, a phantom throb in her left thigh that always picked up the beat of a London drizzle. She pulled the collar of her heavy wool coat tighter, the fabric smelling of damp earth and something vaguely antiseptic, a scent that followed her from one grim location to the next.

This one was an alleyway tucked between a derelict tannery and a pub whose windows were opaque with grime. The air was thick with the ghosts of industry, the tang of iron from the river, and the more recent, cloying sweetness of cheap perfume. A single red shoe, a high heel, lay on its side in a puddle, a splash of defiant colour in a world of grey. It was the only thing left of Amelia Croft, aged twenty-six, a trainee solicitor who’d had the misfortune of taking a shortcut.

"Right then, Doctor," said a voice to her right. Detective Inspector Finch, a man whose weary face looked as though it had been carved from a block of lard and left too near a radiator. "He's done it again. Same as the others."

Aris didn't look at him. Her eyes were fixed on the wall. "Not quite the same, Inspector."

Finch sighed, a sound like a punctured tyre. "Woman goes missing. No witnesses. No struggle. Leaves a bit of herself behind. Looks the same to me."

"The stain," Aris said, her voice low. It was a flat, northern tone, a Salford burr that hadn't been softened by years in the army or months in the capital. It made Londoners either listen closer or dismiss her entirely. Finch was still deciding which. "It's bigger."

On the grimy brick, a smear of impossible, lurid yellow. It wasn’t paint, not precisely. Aris had seen the lab reports on the samples from the other three scenes. Inconclusive. Organic compounds mixed with industrial pigments, traces of sulphur and something protein-based they couldn't identify. It had the texture of dried egg yolk and the faint, unsettling smell of ozone and damp clay. This time, it wasn't just a splash. It was a wide, sweeping arc, starting near the ground and curving up, up, over seven feet high, ending in what looked horribly like the imprint of a massive thumb. As if something had casually leaned against the wall, bracing itself, before plucking a woman from the world.

Aris crouched down, ignoring the damp seeping into the knees of her trousers. She ran a gloved finger near the edge of the red shoe. The ground around it was scuffed, but not in the way you’d expect from a fight. It was a single, deep impression, a divot in the compacted earth of the alley. She looked from the divot to the yellow thumbprint high on the wall. The geometry of it was all wrong. The physics were a lie.

"Any other anomalies?" she asked, her gaze sweeping the narrow space. The police search had been thorough in its own plodding way. They’d looked for fibres, for footprints, for discarded weapons. They were looking for a man. Aris knew, with a certainty that chilled her more than the rain, that they were looking for the wrong thing.

"Just the usual," Finch grumbled. "Bin's been knocked over down the end."

Aris stood, her joints cracking a soft protest. She walked the length of the alley, her boots crunching on loose gravel. The industrial bin was on its side, its contents—sodden cardboard and the refuse of the pub—spilled across the ground. But it wasn't just knocked over. One side was deeply concave, a huge dent in the thick sheet metal, as if it had been kicked by a horse. Or squeezed. She saw something else, too. A piece of iron drainpipe, thick as her wrist, had been bent at a ninety-degree angle where it jutted from the wall, about five feet up. It was snapped clean from its housing. She touched the cold, fractured metal. The force required… it was absurd.

"That's new," she murmured to herself.

Finch had waddled up behind her. "Vandals. Kids. Happens all the time."

"Does it, Inspector?" Aris turned to face him, her eyes, the colour of a stormy sea, holding his. "In the same alley, on the same night that a woman vanishes into thin air, leaving behind a stain of unidentifiable biological matter and a thumbprint the size of a dinner plate?"

Finch’s jowls wobbled. He looked from her to the bent pipe and back again. The certainty in his own procedural world was beginning to crack. "What are you suggesting, Doctor? That the Incredible Hulk’s come to South London for a bit of a sing-song?"

"I'm suggesting we stop ignoring the details that don't fit the narrative of a man with a van and a bag of lime." She pulled a small sampling kit from her coat pocket, scraping a flake of the yellow substance from the high thumbprint into a vial. The brick was rough under her scraper, but the yellow material came away cleanly, like a scab. "He's getting bolder. Or hungrier."

Back in the sterile white box they called her office, a temporary space in a forgotten corner of New Scotland Yard, the files of the other victims were spread across her desk. Three women before Amelia Croft. There was Elodie, the ballerina, who disappeared from a Covent Garden side street. Her ballet slipper was left, filled with rainwater. Then came Maria, the cellist, taken from outside a rehearsal hall in Islington. They found her cello case, empty, with a single, furious yellow slash across it. And then Chloe, the soup kitchen volunteer, who vanished from a street in Whitechapel, leaving only a dropped ladle.

Dancer. Musician. Charity worker. Solicitor. Aris stared at their photographs. They were all different ages, different backgrounds, different ethnicities. But they all had it. A light in their eyes. In the photos, they were all laughing, or smiling, or caught in a moment of unguarded joy. They were women who shone. It wasn't about sex or money. It was about something else entirely. It was about their radiance. He was a collector of lights, and he extinguished them one by one, leaving only his own jaundiced signature in their place.

Jealousy. The thought came to her unbidden, sharp and clear. It was a motive as old as humanity, but this felt different. Primal. This wasn't the bitter envy of a spurned lover or a failed colleague. This was something vaster. The jealousy of a shadow for the sun.

She pulled up the crime scene photographs on her monitor, flicking between them. Elodie’s scene: a snapped iron railing on a nearby fence, noted in the file as 'pre-existing urban decay'. Maria’s scene: a heavy stone planter, cracked from top to bottom, 'likely frost damage'. Chloe’s scene: a brick wall, crumbled, 'poor-quality mortar'. And now, Amelia's scene, with its crushed bin and bent drainpipe.

Finch and his ilk saw a dozen unrelated acts of minor vandalism. Aris Leach, who had once put a man back together after he’d been hit by an IED, who knew precisely what kinetic energy did to bone and metal, saw a single, terrifying pattern. She saw the tracks of something impossibly strong. Something huge.

She leaned back, the cheap office chair groaning. The city hummed outside her window, a sprawling, indifferent beast. Four women gone. A giant, fuelled by envy, stalking the streets of London, eating women who shone too brightly and painting their memory yellow. It sounded like a madman's fairytale, a forgotten piece of grotesque folklore come to life. But the samples in her lab and the ache in her leg told her it was real. The press, in their predictable fashion, had dubbed him the 'Canary Killer'. They had no idea how inadequate the name was.

Her phone buzzed. It was a text from her liaison at the lab. *'Preliminary on the new sample. Same composition. But the protein markers are… different. More concentrated. And Aris… we found traces of human digestive enzymes.'*

Aris closed her eyes. It wasn't just a signature. It wasn't just paint. It was a byproduct. A regurgitation. The final, disgusting insult. He painted them yellow because that was what was left of them inside him.

She opened her eyes, stood up, and walked to the window. The lights of London glittered below, millions of tiny lives, millions of little flames in the dark. One of them was a monster. And she, a doctor of medicine and a veteran of a forgotten war, a woman from the rain-soaked streets of Salford, was the only person who seemed to see the size of the shadow he cast. A cold resolve settled over her, heavy and familiar as her coat. Right then. Let’s get to it. The city was a hunting ground, and the game was afoot.

She shrugged back into the heavy wool coat, the motion automatic, the familiar weight a strange comfort against the formless dread coalescing inside her. The office suddenly felt too small, its white walls a closing trap. She swept the victims' files back into a single, neat pile, handling their faces with a reverence that felt inadequate. They deserved justice, but the word felt thin and brittle when faced with the reality of what had happened to them. They hadn't just been murdered; they had been consumed, rendered down to their basest components, and what was left was a mocking, yellow smear on a grimy wall. Justice seemed a paltry thing to offer in return for such an obscene violation.

The walk to the deep-level labs was a descent, both literally and figuratively. She left the drab carpets and bureaucratic hum of the main floors behind, taking a dedicated lift down into the building’s concrete heart. Here, the air was chilled and scrubbed clean, the corridors were painted a sterile, glossy white, and the silence was broken only by the whir of ventilation and the quiet beeping of machines that spent their days searching for truth in the microscopic. It was a world away from the grime of the Southwark alley, yet Aris felt the connection between the two places like an electric current. This was where the monster’s spoor was dissected, where its nature would be laid bare, if only they had the courage to look.

Ben Carter was waiting for her in Lab 3. He was a decade younger than her, a wiry man with hair that stood up in a permanent state of surprise and eyes that were magnified by thick glasses. He practically vibrated with a nervous intelligence that Aris found both exhausting and useful. He had already projected the mass spectrometer readings onto a large wall-mounted screen. A chaotic festival of coloured peaks and troughs, it was a language she only partially understood.
"Aris. It's weirder than I thought," he said, skipping any pleasantries. He pointed a laser at a jagged series of green spikes on the screen. "Standard human proteome on the left. That's the baseline, from residual skin cells on the shoe. On the right… that's the yellow stuff. The primary proteins are human, yes. But they're sheared, hydrolysed—basically, torn to shreds. And the enzymes that did it…" He zoomed in on another section, a flurry of angry-looking red lines. "Pepsin, trypsin, sure. But there's something else mixed in, a catalyst I've never seen before. It works like a super-acid, but it’s organic. It breaks down everything, collagen, keratin, even the enamel of teeth, at a terrifying rate. There shouldn’t be anything left, but it seems… inefficient."

Aris stared at the data, the abstract lines translating into a horrific mental image. A digestive system of impossible power, yet somehow sloppy. "In a normal digestive tract, the enzymes are contained. They break down food, the nutrients are absorbed, waste is… processed," she said, her voice quiet. "This is different. This is like the whole process happened externally, or was violently reversed."
"Exactly!" Ben’s excitement was macabre. "It’s like a flash-digestion followed by a… purge. A regurgitation. The killer isn't leaving a mark, Doctor. He's leaving his vomit. And the concentration is off the charts this time. The previous samples were faint traces. This one is potent. It suggests the digestive process is becoming more effective. Or, as you put it, he’s getting hungrier."

A profound, visceral sickness rose in her. It wasn't just envy. It was predation. The creature stalking London wasn't a collector of lights; it was a consumer of them. It was feeding on the very essence of these women, on the vitality she had recognised in their photographs. The increased strength, the growing boldness, the more concentrated stain—it was all part of a single, terrifying metabolic process. The monster was growing. It was adapting to its new hunting ground. She thought of the bent drainpipe, the crushed bin. It wasn't just showing off. It was testing its own strength, like a growing adolescent. The thought was so bizarre, so far outside the realm of normal police work, that she almost laughed. The Incredible Hulk, Finch had scoffed. He was closer than he knew.

"Ben," she said, turning away from the screen, her sea-grey eyes locking onto his. "Look into mythology. Folklore. Anything you can find, from any culture, about creatures that feed on… life-force. On vitality. Things that are drawn to brightness, to joy."
Ben’s magnified eyes blinked. "You want me to run a search on… folkloric predators? In the Met's forensic database?"
"No," Aris corrected, her Salford accent clipping the word. "I want you to use your own considerable, and I suspect, non-regulation access to every university and occult library database on the planet. Forget police procedure. The thing we're hunting doesn't follow it. We're looking for a fairytale, Ben. A horrible, grimy, real-life fairytale that has crawled into London to feed." She saw the flicker of doubt in his eyes, warring with the sheer, undeniable weirdness of the science in front of him. "Just do it," she added, her voice softening slightly. "Humour me. What have we got to lose?"

Ben didn't need any more encouragement. The prospect of chasing a genuine scientific anomaly, even one wrapped in the archaic language of myth, was more than enough to set his formidable mind to the task. Aris left him to it, the door to the lab hissing shut behind her, sealing him in with his screens and his strange new quest. The lift ascended silently, carrying her back up through the layers of the building, each floor she passed a step further away from the cold, hard data and a step closer to the incomprehensible reality it described. The certainty she had felt in the lab began to fray at the edges, replaced by the professional loneliness of knowing something that you could never, ever say aloud. It was one thing to entertain a theory about a monster in the sterile confines of a forensics lab; it was another to carry that knowledge out into the corridors of power, where men like Finch carved the world into neat, manageable boxes.

As if summoned by the thought, the Inspector was waiting for her when the lift doors opened, his bulk filling the narrow hallway. He was holding a flimsy sheet of paper as if it were a winning lottery ticket, a rare glimmer of satisfaction momentarily smoothing the deep-set lines of his face. He’d found a piece that fit his puzzle, and he was proud of it.
“Good news, Doctor,” he announced, the words rumbling in his chest. “We’ve got a person of interest. Name’s Gary Tibbett. Local bloke, lives a few streets over from the Croft girl’s alley. Got a record as long as your arm for harassment, indecent exposure. Likes to follow women home from the tube station. One of his previous victims said he threatened to ‘swallow her whole’. Fits the profile.”

Aris took the paper he offered. It was a standard background check, a photograph of a sallow-faced man with shifty eyes and a weak chin stapled to the corner. She could see why Finch was pleased. Tibbett was a perfect fit for a conventional crime. He was the piece you found and slotted into place, the ugly but simple answer that allowed everyone to sleep at night. But he was the wrong piece for this puzzle. She could feel it with the same instinct that made her shrapnel ache before the rain. She pictured Gary Tibbett, with his thin wrists and sloping shoulders, trying to crush a steel bin or snap a cast iron drainpipe. The image was laughable.
“And his alibi?” she asked, handing the paper back.
“At home with his mum, of course,” Finch said, the satisfaction already beginning to sour in the face of her lack of enthusiasm. “But she’s half-senile and he’s a proven liar.”
“Check his hands, Inspector,” Aris said, her voice flat. “Look for any bruising, any fractures. Ask him to lift a hundred kilograms with one arm. Ask him if he can jump seven feet from a standing start.”
Finch’s face began to revert to its usual melted state. “Now look here, Doctor. This is how we solve cases. We find the grubby little man with the nasty little habit and we put him away. We don't go looking for circus strongmen. Tibbett is a solid lead.”
“He’s a distraction,” Aris countered, her patience, a finite resource at the best of times, wearing dangerously thin. “He is the noise that stops you from hearing the signal. You are looking for a man who preys on the vulnerable. The person we are hunting, the thing we are hunting, does the opposite. It seeks out strength. It’s drawn to confidence, to talent, to joy. It doesn’t want the women who walk with their heads down. It wants the ones who shine.”

She pushed past him, not waiting for a response, and walked back into the sterile box of her office. The conversation had crystallised her thinking. It wasn't just about the victims’ inner light; it was about how they projected it. A ballerina on a Covent Garden stage, a cellist whose music filled a hall, a solicitor arguing a case, a charity worker whose compassion was a beacon in a place like Whitechapel. They were all performers in their own way, projecting their essence out into the world. And something had seen them. Something had coveted that energy and come to consume it. She went to the large map of London pinned to a corkboard on her wall, a relic from a previous, more geographically-focused investigation. She took four coloured pins from a drawer and began to push them into the map. Elodie in Covent Garden. Maria in Islington. Chloe in Whitechapel. Amelia in Southwark.

For a long time she just stared at them, four tiny points of plastic representing four extinguished lives. ### Chapter 9

The metal groaned faintly under her weight, the sound echoing down into the vast, silent chamber, but the sleeping heart of the crystal did not stir. The console hummed to life as her fingers brushed its surface, the dark glass illuminating with a complex, holographic display of swirling star-charts, cascading equations, and pulsating waveforms. With her heart hammering against her ribs, she bypassed the minimal security—pride, not caution, had designed this system—and found the primary data repository. The main lights in the chamber extinguished, plunging the vast space into a deeper darkness, broken only by the pulsing violet heart of the crystal. The thousands of lenses and antennae on the walls began to glow with a soft, blue light, and a low, resonant hum filled the air, a single, pure bass note that vibrated through the metal catwalk and into the marrow of her bones. It was a message, a galactic encyclopedia, a cosmic Rosetta Stone being broadcast from a forgotten corner of the Scottish Highlands, and its sheer, alien intellect was a physical blow.

Her training fought back against the tide of overwhelming awe. Her mind, a fortress built of discipline and trauma, slammed its shutters against the sublime terror of the broadcast and focused on the single, vital task. The thin green line of the progress bar. It crept forward, a snail’s pace against the lightning-fast cascade of alien data. Ninety-two percent. The catwalk beneath her feet began to vibrate violently, not from a simple mechanical shudder, but from a sympathetic resonance with the immense power being channelled through the chamber. The pulsing heart of the crystal was no longer a soft violet but a blinding, searing magnesium-white, a miniature sun that bleached all colour from the world, casting sharp, dancing shadows that seemed to have a life of their own. The crescendo arrived not with a bang, but with a moment of absolute, perfect tonal clarity. The shriek coalesced into a single, pure note of impossible pitch and power. At that instant, a column of coherent, shimmering energy, a solid beam of visible information, erupted from the apex of the crystal. Ninety-nine percent. The beam of light held steady, a pillar connecting the heart of the Earth to the cold, listening dark of space.

The blinding white light of the crystal faded, returning to its soft, violet, sleeping pulse. The thousands of glowing lenses on the chamber walls went dark, plunging the vast space into a near-absolute blackness, broken only by the faint glow of the console and the crystal’s distant heart. She ripped the device from the console just as the holographic display changed, the beautiful, complex song replaced by a single, stark, red message in plain, brutal English. *EXTERNAL DATA BREACH DETECTED. ### Chapter 10

The sixty-second countdown was not a threat; it was a death sentence delivered in the cold, impartial language of a machine. There was no time for awe, no room for terror. Aris’s mind, stripped bare of everything but the primal imperative to survive, became a realm of pure, cold calculation. Sixty seconds to cross one hundred feet of exposed gantry, exit a magnetically sealed door, and clear the blast radius of a weapon she could not begin to comprehend. She hit the gravel outside hard, rolling to dissipate the impact, the rough stones tearing at her clothes and skin. Stumbling through the dark, guided by instinct and the faint outline of the hills against the sky, she made her way back towards the ravine, back towards the world of the living, a fugitive carrying a ghost in a box.
